oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ashwood Hall entrance
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Front view of Ashwood Hall, Columbia, Tennessee, showing seven unidentified individuals. The home has full-length windows, Corinthian columns, a triangular pediment, and iron railing. Two wings with porches extend from the main block.

Ashwood Hall, known as the Marble Mansion, was built for Bishop Leonidas Polk in the 1830's. The house was later sold to Andrew Jackson Polk, who had the home expanded. The home was destroyed by a fire in 1874.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Calvert Brothers
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Dwellings--Tennessee; Architecture, Domestic--Tennessee
Houses; Columns; Corinthian order; Mansions
